I don't think I said it's perfectly fine.  We continue to evaluate pacing after every early season patch. In addition to greater than usual change, the MMR of games isn't quite as tight because people haven't settled. This often leads to the feeling of more wonky games. Sometimes even shorter ones.

In the first game you posted, the enemy team had a Veigar and a Vayne.  They were banking on making a long game.  They didn't get there, and lost.  There's value in being able to stop hyperscalers by ending games. There's also value in games coming to an end when they're clearly out of hand and people just want them to be over (generally the people losing).

Picking and choosing small samples of data can also lead to a very skewed picture. Over your ten games on January 1 (per euw.op.gg, not sure if their date/timing is right), your average game time was 30 minutes.  Over your last ten ranked games that I see you have a 35, 26, 30, and 25 minute game, though on a whole they do seem fast!  You're also climbing rapidly: you were Gold last season and now are D4.  You're doing suspiciously well and playing early game champions for the most part. If the system doesn't know your actual MMR you will tend to get more skewed games.

well, according to leagueofgraphs every elo better than bronze closes games in less than 30min, up to an average gametime of ~25:40 in challenger ...that´s not even 6min after you´d be allowed to surrender, which in S2 marked the point when laning ended and midgame started for the most part. Now there´s just not much game outside the laning phase - it´s win lane and then close out for players that somwhat understand how to close out a lead. 

So for many players you spent the last two years killing the actual fun part of the game where makro-play is in full effect and you really needed to work together as a team and strategize to win a game...which also made every game feel different as there had been so much stuff going on lategame, and there really were lots of different comps. In the last year of proplay i´ve rarly even heard someone analysing the teamcomp of any team as as a poke or dive or protect or anything-comp - as no team cared at all, they just picked the strongest meta champs and fr the most part early game powerhouses and strong laners. That´s all the strategy they had.

So well, the game really is in a sad state for about anyone that fell in love with it during S1-3.

I've seen people become so worked up over getting to open another box that in another universe they could have just found out their kid got accepted into a great university.

And never a day goes by where people either get excited, or miserable, from what meaningless letter got assigned to their performance, when half the time it doesn't even seem like the grading system even understands playing extremely well and hard-carrying a match.
